Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of Iron Transport in Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Iron is essential for many aspects of an animal's life, but iron is also potentially toxic. Because iron is both necessary and harmful, the amount, location and form of iron within an animal must be tightly controlled. In humans and other mammals, the physiological processes that provide the right amount of iron at the right times are partially understood. However, in insects and other invertebrate animals, these processes have not yet been discovered. The goal of this research project is to understand how iron is transported from one cell to another in insects using the fruit fly as a model system. The project will provide research experiences for undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds. Knowledge gained from this research will provide a framework for future studies of iron transport in blood-feeding insects such as mosquitoes, which must cope with a seemingly toxic amount of iron when they ingest a blood meal. A potential outcome of this project is the discovery of a more evolutionarily ancient iron transport mechanism that functions not only in insects but also in other invertebrate animals. In addition, information learned from this research may provide insight into the less-understood mechanisms of iron transport in humans. Finally, because insect management strategies rely on information about insect biology, the results of this project may contribute to the development of a new insect control strategy.

The goal of the proposed research is to understand the physiological mechanisms of iron transport in insects. Four models that describe possible mechanisms of iron transport into cells will be tested using Drosophila melanogaster as the model insect species. OBJECTIVE 1: The first objective is to test the hypothesis that receptor-mediated endocytosis of iron-loaded ferritin or ferric-transferrin transports iron from hemolymph into cells. 1A) Ferritin and transferrin will be labeled with a fluorophore and then observed to determine whether cellular uptake occurs. 1B) Confocal microscopy will be used to evaluate whether ferritin or transferrin are present in endosomes. 1C) Essential components of the endocytosis pathways will be blocked, and the effect on iron uptake will be measured. OBJECTIVE 2: The second objective is to test the hypothesis that reduction of ferric ions in hemolymph leads to iron transport into cells. Hemolymph contains iron in the ferric form, but iron transporters in animals are specific to ferrous iron; therefore, iron uptake via an influx transporter is likely to require a reduction step. The functions of a known ferric reductase, CG8399, and a candidate ferric reductase, CG1275, will be studied. 2A) RNAi will be used to determine whether CG8399 or CG1275 contribute to cell surface ferric reductase activity. 2B) RNAi will be used to determine whether the activity of CG8399 or CG1275 influences the iron content of cells. 2C) A membrane-impermeant ferrous chelator will be evaluated for its ability to inhibit iron uptake.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research at Metropolitan State University of Denver (MSU Denver) is part of a collaborative project with a research team at Kansas State University (K-State). Together we are working to understand how insect cells take up iron. Iron is an essential mineral for life because it is a key functional component of many important proteins. For example, the protein that carries oxygen in our blood needs iron to bind to the oxygen. That iron ion is part of a heme group. Other important iron-containing proteins are part of the electron transport chain, which is the major way we harvest energy from the food we eat. Another interesting group of proteins that require iron are cytochrome b561 proteins, which bind two heme groups in their central cavity. These cytochrome b561 proteins transfer an electron from one side of the membrane to another. This electron comes from vitamin C and is used, in at least some cases, to reduce an iron(III) ion to an iron(II) ion. The iron(II) ion is then able to pass through a transport protein to enter a cell. A human cytochrome b561 protein, Dcytb, reduces iron(III) to allow its uptake from the intestine, thus providing a key way to absorb iron.

Our work has focused on understanding cellular iron uptake in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster. Insect systems like the fruit fly are useful to study because they are simpler than humans, yet insights made in insects can shed light on related processes in humans. Additionally, a better understanding of insect physiology can help us control dangerous insect populations and support the health of beneficial insects. An important way human cells take up iron is through uptake of an iron-binding protein called transferrin. The K-State team solved the 3D structure of an insect transferrin (transferrin 1) and found it only binds one iron ion, instead of two iron ions like human serum transferrin. They also performed genetic experiments to show that transferrin-1 is not essential for insects. The transferrin receptor in humans is important for iron uptake into human cells, but no transferrin receptor has been found in insects. Clearly insects don’t rely on transferrin for cellular iron uptake the way many human cells do. We studied cytochrome b561 proteins in the fruit fly and other insect species to evaluate which are most likely to have a role in iron transport, and we identified three promising candidates.

MSU Denver is a primarily undergraduate institution, so our research program is providing valuable training for undergraduates interested in pursing careers as scientists. At MSU Denver we offered intensive research training experiences to 21 students and brought aspects of research into a lecture course to expand student experience with research in a course context. Our research students used a technique called RNAi to decrease the amount of two cytochrome b561 proteins in cultured insect cells. These cells were still able to grow and divide, despite having less cytochrome b561 protein. We also measured the amount of iron in insect cells using a reagent that turns a pink color when it binds iron. When the COVID-19 pandemic prevented us from continuing research in the laboratory, we switched to studying insect cytochrome b561 proteins using tools on our computers. We found that there are four distinct groups of insect cytochrome b561s, two of which are similar to human Dcytb in important ways like potential iron and vitamin C binding residues. 

The classroom aspect of our project involved development of a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) for Biochemistry II, an upper-division lecture course at MSU Denver. A CURE allows all students in a course to participate in a research experience that addresses an authentic scientific problem. Students have the potential to make discoveries, engage in trouble-shooting, and communicate results to other stakeholders. “A Bioinformatic Look at Iron Uptake in Insects” impacted 107 students between Spring 2018 and Spring 2020. Groups of students studied fruit fly genes and proteins that are we believe are involved in iron homeostasis. Resources related to the Spring 2019 CURE are available at CUREnet. Some student groups made discoveries that advanced our project. For example, groups investigating CG1275 identified a lysosomal targeting sequence. They also found that residues assumed to be involved in vitamin C binding in early reports are instead involved in heme binding. A modified version of a CURE survey was given to students each semester. Our data indicate that our CURE in a lecture class was valuable in some of the same ways as CUREs that are part of lab classes.
